text: To convey disgust in writing, authors often employ vivid descriptions that evoke a strong sense of revulsion. Commonly used words and phrases include "retch," "gag," "sour," "putrid," "foul," and "repugnant." More elaborate descriptions might involve "the stench of decay," "a slimy residue," or "bile rising in the throat." Authors may also use metaphors like "a festering wound" or "a vile concoction" to emphasize the unpleasantness. These tools help writers effectively transmit the visceral reaction of disgust to their audience.

text: Certainly. Neutral expressions often use words and phrases that convey a balanced, impartial tone. Examples include: "It is widely acknowledged that," "Some argue," "On one hand," "On the other hand," "In some cases," and "Notably." These phrases help maintain a neutral stance, allowing readers to form their own opinions without being swayed by biased language. Neutral writing can also employ words like "apparently," "allegedly," and "reportedly" to convey information without taking a stance.
